case_name: Parshotam Lal v. General Manager, Northern Railway

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 65 of 1957 filed by appellant against Punjab High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 65 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 1, 1956, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Letters Patent Appeal No. 28 of 1955

facts.text: Punjab High Court Division Bench judgment and order dated January 19, 1956 in Letters Patent Appeal No. 28 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: It is directed against the judgment and order passed by a Division Bench of that companyrt on January 19, 1956, in Letters Patent Appeal No. 28 of 1955, reversing the judgment and order of Mr. Justice Harnam Singh pronounced on April 15, 1955

facts.text: Single Judge Mr. Justice Harnam Singh allowed Civil Writ No. 36-D of 1955 on April 15, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: reversing the judgment and order of Mr. Justice Harnam Singh pronounced on April 15, 1955, whereby his Lordship had allowed the appellants application being Civil Writ No. 36-D of 1955

facts.text: Certificate of fitness granted by Punjab High Court on August 20, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been filed with a certificate of fitness granted by the Punjab High companyrt on August 20. 1956.

facts.text: Appellant joined railway service as Signaller Telegraphist in August 1924.

anchor.surface_text: In August 1924 the appellant joined the railway service as a Signaller  Telegraphist .

facts.text: Appellant promoted to Section Controller in 1942.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of selection, he was promoted as Section Controller in 1942

facts.text: Appellant promoted to Deputy Chief Controller in 1947.

anchor.surface_text: and as Deputy Chief Controller in 1947 and as the Chief Controller in 1950.

facts.text: Appellant promoted to Chief Controller in 1950, Class III service.

anchor.surface_text: All these posts were in Class III service. On March 31, 1951, seven candidates

facts.text: On March 31, 1951, appellant selected by selection board for Assistant Superintendent Railway Telegraphs, Class II post.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1951, seven candidates, including the appellant, appeared before a selection board companystituted for selecting a candidate for the post of Assistant Superintendent Railway Telegraphs, which was a gazetted post in Class 11 Officers cadre.

facts.text: Appointment notice issued July 2, 1951 to appellant to officiate as Asst. Spdt. Rly. Telegraphs.

anchor.surface_text: On July 2, 1951, a numberice of appointment was issued from the headquarters of the East Punjab Railway, Delhi, numberifying that Mr. Parshotam Lal, Officiating Chief Controller, is appointed to officiate in Class II service as Asstt. Spdt. Rly. Telegraphs

facts.text: Appellant relieved Mr. Sahu Ram on afternoon of July 3, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The applicant actually relieved Mr. Sahu Ram in the afternoon of July 3, 1951.

facts.text: Adverse remarks by Gouri Shankar S.T.E.I. Hd. Qrs. on April 28, 1953 in confidential report for year ending March 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on April 28, 1953, one Gouri Shankar S.T.E.I. Hd. Qrs. made certain adverse remarks against the appellant in his companyfidential report for the year ending March 31, 1953.

facts.text: Shri Sen, C.S.T.E. confirmed adverse views on May 25, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: This companyfidential report came before Shri Sen, C.S.T.E., on May 25,1953, who companyfirmed the views expressed by Shri Gouri Shankar

facts.text: General Manager Shri Karnail Singh remarked on June 11, 1953: disappointed, should revert.

anchor.surface_text: the aforesaid remarks were placed before the General Manager, Shri Karnail Singh, who on June 11, 1953, remarked thereon as follows I am disappointed to read these reports. He should revert as a subordinate till he makes good the short-comings

facts.text: Adverse remarks communicated to appellant by confidential letter No. E-106/180 dated June 29, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The adverse remarks against the appellant in the companyfidential report for the year ending March 31, 1953, which were companymunicated to the appellant for his information by a companyfidential letter No. E-106/180 dated June 29, 1953

facts.text: Appellant made representation against remarks on July 24, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On July 24, 1953, the appellant, who had by this time earned two increments on July 4, 1952 and July 4, 1953, made a representation against the remarks made against him.

facts.text: General Manager issued notice No. 940-E/14 E.I.A. on August 19, 1953 reverting appellant to Class III.

anchor.surface_text: On August 19, 1953, however, numberice No. 940-E/14  E.I.A.  was issued by the General Manager  P  to the following effect Shri Bishambar Nath Chopra, Instructor Railway Training School, Saharnpur, is transferred to Headquarters office and appointed to officiate in Class 11 service as Assistant Signal and Tele-communication Engineer  Telegraphs  vice Shri Parshotam Lal Dhingra, who on relief reverts to Class III appointment.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to General Manager on August 20, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant on August 20, 1953, appealed to the General Manager for reconsideration

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Railway Board and represented to President on October 19, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter on October 19, 1953, appealed to the Railway Board and made a representation also to the President of India.

facts.text: Railway Board letter to General Manager on February 2, 1955: reversion stands but not bar to future promotion.

anchor.surface_text: On February 2, 1955, the Railway Board wrote to the General Manager as follows With reference to your letter No. 3780 dated the 30th December, 1953, the Board desires that you should inform Shri Parshotam Lal Dhingra that his reversion for generally unsatisfactory work will stand, but that this reversion will number be a bar to his being companysidered again for a promotion in the future if his work and companyduct justify.

facts.text: Railway Board communication to petitioner on February 17, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: This was companymunicated to the petitioner on February 17, 1955.

facts.text: Petitioner filed writ petition under Art. 226 on February 9, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime the petitioner had on February 9, 1955, filed his writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds reversion order of August 19, 1953 not reduction in rank under Art. 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances there is numberescape from the companyclusion that the petitioner was number reduced in rank by way of punishment and, therefore, the provisions of Art. 311  2  do number companye into play at all.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal must, therefore, be dismissed with companyts.
In the meantime the petitioner had on February 9, 1955, filed his writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution.
This appeal raises a very important question about the construction of art. 311 of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supports qualified pleasure doctrine under Arts. 310-311

holdings.text: Article 311 applies to all government servants including those in permanent, temporary, quasi-permanent, probationary, and officiating capacities without distinction.

anchor.surface_text: The question for our consideration is whether the protections of Art. 311 are available to each of these several categories of Government servants. A number of decisions bearing on the question of construction of Arts. 310 and 311 have been cited before us which indicate that there is some difference of opinion between the Judges of the different High Courts and in some cases amongst the Judges of the same High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of Arts. 310 and 311 shows no distinction between permanent and temporary; limiting to permanent adds words contrary to principles; overruling contrary High Court decisions.

holdings.text: The expressions 'dismissed', 'removed' or 'reduced in rank' in Article 311(2) refer to the three major punishments under service rules requiring procedural safeguards.

anchor.surface_text: What, then, is the meaning of those expressions dismissed, removed or reduced in rank? It has been said in Jayanti Prasad... Thus the service rules... selected the three graver punishments

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical evolution from 1920/1930 Classification Rules and Railway Code shows these as major penalties with special procedures lifted into Constitution.

holdings.text: Termination of service constitutes punishment under Article 311(2) only if (1) the servant had a right to the post or rank, or (2) the order visits the servant with penal consequences such as loss of seniority, pay, or future promotion chances.

anchor.surface_text: One test for determining whether the termination of the service of a Government servant is by way of punishment is to ascertain whether the servant had the right to hold the post or whether visited with penal consequences.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balancing pleasure doctrine with protections; applies two-pronged test distinguishing normal termination from punitive based on rights forfeiture or evil consequences; synthesizes service rules and precedents.

holdings.text: The reversion order dated August 19, 1953, does not amount to reduction in rank by way of punishment under Article 311(2) as the appellant held the Class II post only on an officiating basis with no substantive right and no penal consequences ensued.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the principles discussed above it is quite clear that the petitioner before us was appointed to the higher post on an officiating basis... Nor did this reduction under Note 1 to r. 1702 amount to his dismissal or removal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fact-specific application of two-pronged test to railway rules and orders: officiating per r.2003(19) terminable at will; Railway Board confirmed no bar to future promotion.

holdings.text: Public servants hold office during the pleasure of the President/Governor subject to express constitutional qualifications in Article 311.

anchor.surface_text: Article 310(1) and Art. 311 omitting the proviso to cl. (2) are as follows... Subject to these exceptions our Constitution, by Art. 310(1), has adopted the English Common Law rule... qualified by Art. 311.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical tracing from English common law through GOI Acts 1915/1935 to Constitution confirms qualified pleasure doctrine.

holdings.text: The appeal is dismissed with costs, upholding the Division Bench judgment.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal must, therefore, be dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of holdings to facts results in no Art. 311 violation.

holdings.text: Article 311 protections are attracted even for officiating servants if a right is infringed or penal consequences beyond normal termination ensue (dissent).

anchor.surface_text: Bose J.-With great respect I cannot agree that Art. 311 is not attracted in this case. I agree with my Lord that Art. 311 applies to all classes of Government servants...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Broader view: infringement of service conditions rights triggers Art. 311 regardless of substantive right; reversion here carries penal consequences.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that we uphold the decision of the Division Bench, although on somewhat different grounds. This appeal must, therefore, be dismissed with costs.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed upholding the Division Bench decision which reversed the Single Judge and dismissed the writ petition; reversion order upheld as not a reduction in rank under Art. 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: The question for our consideration is whether the protections of Art. 311 are available to each of these several categories of Government servants. A number of decisions bearing on the question of construction of Arts. 310 and 311 have been cited before us which indicate that there is some difference of opinion between the Judges of the different High Courts and in some cases amongst the Judges of the same High Court.
The result, therefore, is that we uphold the decision of the Division Bench, although on somewhat different grounds. This appeal must, therefore, be dismissed with costs.
